document.heading: PUEBLO DE SAN ILDEFONSO COUNCIL RESOLUTION NO. SI-R17-022
document.law-heading: SUPPLEMENTAL INDIAN EDUCATION PROGRAM MODERNIZATIONACT OF 2017 (S. 943)
document.resolution-preamble: At a duly called meeting of the Council of San Ildefonso Pueblo on the 11th day of August , 2017, the following Resolution was adopted:

recital.text: the Pueblo de San Ildefonso ("Pueblo') is a sovereign and self-governing Tribe, recognized as such by the United States of America; and
the Council is authorized to make laws for the Pueblo de San Ildefonso pursuant to Section 5 of the Agreement, the governing document of the Pueblo; and
the Council supports efforts to update and modernize the JOM program and establish true funding level determinations.
that the Council hereby enacts the attached law entitled the "SUPPLEMENTAL INDIAN EDUCATION PROGRAM MODERNIZATION ACT OF 2017 (S. 943)."

procedural-data.text: The foregoing resolution was duly voted upon by the Council on August 11 , 2017, at a meeting with a vote of 9 in favor, 0 opposed, 0 abstaining and 1 absent (Governor presiding and not voting) pursuant to the authority vested in the Council by the Agreement of the Pueblo de San Ildefonso.

attachment.text: SUPPLEMENTAL INDIAN EDUCATION PROGRAM MODERNIZATION ACT OF 2017 (S. 943)

section.heading: Short Title
section.text: This enactment shall be known as the "SUPPLEMENTAL INDIAN EDUCATION PROGRAM MODERNIZATION ACT OF 2017 (S. 943) ("Act")."

section.heading: Purpose
section.text: The purpose of this Act is to support efforts to update and modernize the Johnson O'Malley (JOM) program and establish true funding level determinations.

section.heading: Findings
section.text: The Council hereby finds and declares that:

para.text: The Pueblo de San Ildefonso ("Pueblo") is a federally recognized Indian tribe eligible for the services provided to Indians by the Secretary of the Interior because of the Pueblo's status; and,

The Pueblo advocates for students, ages 3 through high school, who are enrolled in, or eligible for enrollment in, a federally-recognized tribe and not attending or served by Bureau of Indian Education (BIE) schools, and who are currently being served from respective tribal jurisdiction boundaries and service areas; and,

The JOM funding and the certified student count of 278,000 has been at its 1995 level even though, according to data collected by the U.S. Census Bureau in 2010, there are 798,486 American Indian and Alaska Native students in the age group eligible to receive JOM assistance, effectively leaving many students with unmet needs; and,

JOM programs that foster specialized, culturally sensitive, and unique educational programs that develop leadership skills of future tribal leaders necessary to promote positive academic, social, and economic changes in Indian communities will cease to exist without continued and appropriate levels of annual funding from Congress.
The Pueblo supports efforts to update and modernize the JOM program including advocating for true funding level determinations.
The Pueblo hereby approves this Act in support of the enactment of S. 943, which supports the Pueblo's prevailing social and cultural standards, and protects the best interests of the community.
